canonical_explanation.text: The plant kingdom encompasses a wide range of organisms from simple algae to complex flowering plants. Algae are chlorophyll-bearing, largely aquatic, simple, thalloid organisms classified into three classes: Chlorophyceae (green algae with chlorophyll a and b, starch storage, e.g., Chlamydomonas, Spirogyra, Ulva), Phaeophyceae (brown algae with chlorophyll a, c, and fucoxanthin, laminarin and mannitol storage, e.g., Ectocarpus, Fucus, Sargassum), and Rhodophyceae (red algae with chlorophyll a, d, and phycoerythrin, floridean starch storage, e.g., Polysiphonia, Porphyra, Gracilaria). Bryophytes are the simplest land plants, called 'amphibians of the plant kingdom' because they require water for fertilisation. They include liverworts (Marchantia) and mosses (Funaria). The dominant phase is the gametophyte, and the sporophyte is dependent on it. Pteridophytes are the first vascular land plants with true xylem and phloem. They include Selaginella, Equisetum, and ferns (Dryopteris). The dominant phase is the sporophyte, while the gametophyte (prothallus) is small and independent. Gymnosperms are seed-bearing plants without enclosed seeds. The ovules are exposed on megasporophylls. Examples include Pinus, Cycas, and Ginkgo. Angiosperms are flowering plants with seeds enclosed in fruits. They are divided into monocotyledons and dicotyledons. Plant life cycles show alternation of generations between a haploid gametophyte (produces gametes by mitosis) and a diploid sporophyte (produces spores by meiosis). In bryophytes, the gametophyte dominates; in pteridophytes, gymnosperms, and angiosperms, the sporophyte dominates. The progressive reduction of the gametophyte and increasing dominance of the sporophyte is a key evolutionary trend.
rules: Chlorophyceae (green algae): chlorophyll a and b, starch storage, cellulose cell wall; examples: Chlamydomonas, Spirogyra, Ulva.
Phaeophyceae (brown algae): chlorophyll a and c + fucoxanthin, mannitol and laminarin storage; examples: Fucus, Sargassum, Laminaria.
Rhodophyceae (red algae): chlorophyll a and d + phycoerythrin, floridean starch storage; examples: Polysiphonia, Porphyra, Gracilaria.
Bryophytes are 'amphibians of the plant kingdom'; gametophyte is dominant; sporophyte is dependent on gametophyte; require water for fertilisation.
Pteridophytes are the first vascular plants; sporophyte is dominant; gametophyte (prothallus) is small, free-living; examples: Selaginella, Equisetum, Dryopteris.
Gymnosperms bear naked seeds on megasporophylls; ovules not enclosed in ovary; examples: Pinus, Cycas, Ginkgo.
Angiosperms have seeds enclosed in fruits; divided into monocots (one cotyledon) and dicots (two cotyledons).
Alternation of generations: haploid gametophyte (n) alternates with diploid sporophyte (2n); gametes by mitosis, spores by meiosis.
Evolutionary trend: progressive reduction of gametophyte and increasing dominance of sporophyte from bryophytes to angiosperms.
Heterospory (production of two types of spores: microspores and megaspores) is seen in some pteridophytes, all gymnosperms, and all angiosperms.

questions.question_text: The pigment responsible for the brown colour of Phaeophyceae is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fucoxanthin is the dominant accessory pigment in brown algae (Phaeophyceae) that gives them their characteristic brown colour. They also contain chlorophyll a and c.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phycoerythrin gives red algae their colour. Phycocyanin is found in cyanobacteria. While xanthophylls are present in many organisms, fucoxanthin is the specific pigment responsible for the brown colour of Phaeophyceae.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a green alga?
questions.explanation_correct: Spirogyra is a green alga (Chlorophyceae) characterised by spiral chloroplasts. It is commonly found in freshwater habitats and is known for its conjugation method of sexual reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sargassum and Laminaria are brown algae (Phaeophyceae), while Polysiphonia is a red alga (Rhodophyceae). Spirogyra is a classic example of a green alga.

questions.question_text: Red algae can grow at greater depths in the ocean compared to other algae because:

options.text: They have a stronger cell wall
They contain phycoerythrin, which absorbs blue-green light that penetrates deeper waters
They do not require light for photosynthesis
They are parasitic on deep-sea organisms

questions.explanation_correct: Red algae contain the pigment phycoerythrin, which absorbs blue-green wavelengths of light. Since blue-green light penetrates deeper into water than other wavelengths, red algae can photosynthesise at greater depths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell wall strength is unrelated to depth range. All algae require light for photosynthesis. Red algae are not parasitic. Their ability to grow deep is due to phycoerythrin absorbing the blue-green light available at depth.

questions.question_text: The food reserve in Chlorophyceae is:
questions.explanation_correct: Green algae (Chlorophyceae) store food as starch, similar to higher plants. This is consistent with their close evolutionary relationship to land plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mannitol and laminarin are storage products of brown algae. Floridean starch is found in red algae. Glycogen is found in animals and fungi. Green algae store starch.

questions.question_text: An alga is found to contain chlorophyll a and d along with phycoerythrin, and stores floridean starch. It most likely belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: The combination of chlorophyll a and d, phycoerythrin (red pigment), and floridean starch as a food reserve is characteristic of Rhodophyceae (red algae).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorophyceae have chlorophyll a and b with starch storage. Phaeophyceae have chlorophyll a and c with fucoxanthin and laminarin/mannitol storage. Cyanophyceae are prokaryotes. The described features are typical of Rhodophyceae.

questions.question_text:
Match the following algae with their classes:
(i) Volvox — (a) Rhodophyceae
(ii) Fucus — (b) Chlorophyceae
(iii) Porphyra — (c) Phaeophyceae

Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Volvox is a colonial green alga (Chlorophyceae - b). Fucus is a brown alga (Phaeophyceae - c). Porphyra is a red alga (Rhodophyceae - a). The correct matching is (i)-(b), (ii)-(c), (iii)-(a).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Volvox is green (Chlorophyceae), Fucus is brown (Phaeophyceae), and Porphyra is red (Rhodophyceae). Any other matching is incorrect.

questions.question_text: Agar, a commercially important substance used as a culture medium in microbiology, is obtained from:
questions.explanation_correct: Agar is a gelatinous substance obtained from red algae (Rhodophyceae), particularly species like Gelidium and Gracilaria. It is widely used as a culture medium in microbiology and as a food additive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Agar is not obtained from green, brown, or blue-green algae. It is specifically extracted from the cell walls of certain red algae, primarily Gelidium and Gracilaria.

questions.question_text: The plant body of algae is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: The plant body of algae is called a thallus. A thallus is a plant body that is not differentiated into true roots, stems, and leaves. Algae are therefore described as thallophytes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protonema is the filamentous stage in moss development. Prothallus is the gametophyte of ferns. Sporophyte is the diploid phase. The undifferentiated body of algae is called a thallus.

questions.question_text: Bryophytes are called 'amphibians of the plant kingdom' because:

options.text: They can survive in both salt and fresh water
They live on land but require water for sexual reproduction
They can photosynthesise both on land and underwater
They have both plant and animal characteristics

questions.explanation_correct: Bryophytes live on land but are dependent on water for the transfer of male gametes (antherozoids) to the female sex organ. This dual dependency on land and water habitats makes them 'amphibians of the plant kingdom'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The term does not refer to salt/fresh water tolerance, underwater photosynthesis, or plant-animal characteristics. It refers to their dependence on both terrestrial and aquatic environments, specifically needing water for fertilisation.

questions.question_text: In bryophytes, the dominant phase of the life cycle is the:
questions.explanation_correct: In bryophytes, the gametophyte (haploid) is the dominant, independent, photosynthetic phase. The sporophyte is smaller and nutritionally dependent on the gametophyte. This is the reverse of the pattern in vascular plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sporophyte in bryophytes is small and dependent. Prothallus is the gametophyte of ferns, not bryophytes. Protonema is an early developmental stage in mosses. The main plant body in bryophytes is the gametophyte.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of pteridophytes that distinguishes them from bryophytes?

options.text: Presence of vascular tissue (xylem and phloem)

questions.explanation_correct: Pteridophytes are the first land plants to possess vascular tissue (true xylem and phloem), which allows efficient transport of water and nutrients. Bryophytes lack true vascular tissue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both bryophytes and pteridophytes have chlorophyll, reproduce sexually, and grow on land. The key distinguishing feature of pteridophytes is the presence of vascular tissue (xylem and phloem).

questions.question_text: Marchantia is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Marchantia is a classic example of a liverwort (Hepaticopsida). It has a flat, thalloid, dorsiventral body that grows horizontally on moist surfaces. Liverworts are one of the two main groups of bryophytes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Funaria is an example of a moss. Dryopteris is a fern. Pinus is a gymnosperm. Marchantia is specifically a liverwort, characterised by its thalloid gametophyte body.

questions.question_text: The gametophyte of a fern is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The gametophyte of a fern is a small, heart-shaped, independent structure called a prothallus. It bears both antheridia (male) and archegonia (female) sex organs and is photosynthetic but short-lived.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protonema is the filamentous early stage of moss growth. Thallus is the undifferentiated body of algae. Sporangium produces spores. The fern gametophyte is specifically called the prothallus.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pteridophytes shows heterospory?
questions.explanation_correct: Selaginella is a heterosporous pteridophyte, producing two types of spores: large megaspores (in megasporangia) and small microspores (in microsporangia). This is considered a precursor to the seed habit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dryopteris, Adiantum, and Equisetum are homosporous (produce only one type of spore). Selaginella (along with Salvinia and Marsilea) exhibits heterospory among pteridophytes.

questions.question_text: In mosses, the first structure that develops from a germinating spore is the:
questions.explanation_correct: When a moss spore germinates, it first produces a creeping, green, branched filamentous structure called the protonema. This subsequently develops buds that grow into the upright, leafy gametophyte.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The leafy gametophyte develops from buds on the protonema, not directly from the spore. The sporophyte develops after fertilisation. The capsule is part of the sporophyte. The protonema is the first structure to develop.

questions.question_text: In the life cycle of a fern, meiosis occurs during:

options.text: Formation of gametes in the prothallus
Formation of spores in the sporangium

questions.explanation_correct: In ferns, meiosis (reduction division) occurs during spore formation in the sporangia of the sporophyte. The diploid spore mother cells undergo meiosis to produce haploid spores, which germinate to form the gametophyte (prothallus).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spore germination is a mitotic process. Gamete formation in the prothallus occurs by mitosis (since the prothallus is already haploid). Fusion of gametes is fertilisation, not meiosis. Meiosis occurs only during sporogenesis.

questions.question_text: Gymnosperms are characterised by:

options.text: Naked seeds not enclosed in an ovary
Seeds enclosed in a cone-like fruit

questions.explanation_correct: Gymnosperms (literally 'naked seeds') bear seeds that are not enclosed in a fruit or ovary. The ovules lie exposed on the surface of megasporophylls, which are often arranged in cones (strobili).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds enclosed in fruits characterise angiosperms. Bryophytes and pteridophytes lack seeds. Gymnosperm cones are not fruits. The defining feature of gymnosperms is their naked (exposed) seeds.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a gymnosperm?
questions.explanation_correct: Cycas is a gymnosperm, one of the oldest living seed plants. It has palm-like leaves and bears naked ovules on megasporophylls. Other gymnosperms include Pinus, Ginkgo, and Sequoia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ficus is an angiosperm. Marchantia is a bryophyte (liverwort). Spirogyra is a green alga. Cycas is the only gymnosperm among the options.

questions.question_text: Angiosperms differ from gymnosperms in having:

options.text: Ovules enclosed in an ovary and double fertilisation

questions.explanation_correct: Angiosperms are unique in having ovules enclosed within an ovary (which develops into a fruit) and exhibiting double fertilisation (one sperm fuses with the egg, another with polar nuclei to form endosperm). Gymnosperms lack both features.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both angiosperms and gymnosperms have vascular tissue, produce seeds, and have dominant sporophytes. The distinguishing features of angiosperms are the enclosed ovary and double fertilisation.

questions.question_text: Angiosperms are divided into two classes based on the number of:
questions.explanation_correct: Angiosperms are divided into Monocotyledons (one cotyledon in the seed) and Dicotyledons (two cotyledons in the seed). This division also correlates with differences in leaf venation, root system, and flower parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While petal number, stamen number, and ovule number vary among angiosperms, the primary basis for dividing them into monocots and dicots is the number of cotyledons (seed leaves) in the embryo.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a living fossil among gymnosperms?
questions.explanation_correct: Ginkgo biloba (maidenhair tree) is called a living fossil because it is the sole surviving species of an ancient group (order Ginkgoales) that was widespread during the Mesozoic era. Its fossils date back over 200 million years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Cycas is also ancient, Ginkgo biloba is specifically termed a 'living fossil' as it is the only surviving member of its entire order. Pinus and Cedrus are conifers with many living species.

questions.question_text: In gymnosperms, pollination is typically achieved by:
questions.explanation_correct: Gymnosperms are predominantly wind-pollinated (anemophilous). They produce large quantities of lightweight pollen grains that are carried by wind to the exposed ovules. This is consistent with their lack of attractive flowers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insect and animal pollination are characteristic of many angiosperms. Water pollination is rare and seen in some aquatic plants. Gymnosperms primarily rely on wind for pollination due to their exposed ovules and lack of flowers.

questions.question_text: Alternation of generations refers to:

options.text: The alternation between asexual and sexual modes of reproduction in different seasons
The alternation between haploid gametophyte and diploid sporophyte phases in a life cycle
The alternation between different types of gametes
The alternation between vegetative and reproductive growth

questions.explanation_correct: Alternation of generations is the life cycle pattern in which a multicellular haploid gametophyte phase alternates with a multicellular diploid sporophyte phase. Meiosis produces spores, and gametes are formed by mitosis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It does not refer to seasonal reproductive changes, gamete types, or growth phases. Alternation of generations specifically describes the cycling between haploid (gametophyte) and diploid (sporophyte) multicellular phases.

questions.question_text: In the life cycle of a moss, which event marks the transition from the gametophyte to the sporophyte generation?
questions.explanation_correct: Fertilisation (fusion of male and female gametes) produces a diploid zygote, marking the beginning of the sporophyte generation. Meiosis in the sporophyte produces haploid spores, marking the return to the gametophyte generation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meiosis marks the transition from sporophyte to gametophyte. Mitosis does not change ploidy. Spore germination begins gametophyte development. Only fertilisation transitions from the haploid gametophyte to the diploid sporophyte.

questions.question_text: Which of the following shows a progressive evolutionary trend from bryophytes to angiosperms?

options.text: Increasing dominance of the sporophyte and reduction of the gametophyte

questions.explanation_correct: A major evolutionary trend in plant evolution is the progressive dominance of the sporophyte and reduction of the gametophyte. In bryophytes, the gametophyte dominates; in angiosperms, the gametophyte is reduced to just a few cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The gametophyte becomes increasingly reduced (not dominant). Vascular tissue becomes more complex (not lost). The trend is from homospory to heterospory (not the reverse). Sporophyte dominance increases through evolution.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): In bryophytes, the sporophyte is dependent on the gametophyte.
Reason (R): The gametophyte is the dominant, photosynthetic phase in bryophytes.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. In bryophytes, the sporophyte grows attached to and derives nutrition from the gametophyte. This dependency exists because the gametophyte is the dominant, independent, photosynthetic phase. The reason correctly explains the assertion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion and reason are both factually correct. The sporophyte is dependent on the gametophyte precisely because the gametophyte is the main photosynthetic body in bryophytes. The reason adequately explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: Which pigments are present in Phaeophyceae?

options.text: Chlorophyll a, b and xanthophyll only

questions.explanation_correct: Brown algae (Phaeophyceae) contain chlorophyll a and c along with the accessory pigment fucoxanthin, which gives them their characteristic brown colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorophyll a and b with phycoerythrin or xanthophyll alone describes neither Phaeophyceae. Chlorophyll a and d with phycoerythrin describes Rhodophyceae. Phaeophyceae specifically have chlorophyll a, c, and fucoxanthin.

questions.question_text: Chlamydomonas, Volvox, and Ulva are examples of algae that belong to the same class because they all:

options.text: Contain chlorophyll a and b and store starch
Are found only in marine habitats

questions.explanation_correct: Chlamydomonas (unicellular), Volvox (colonial), and Ulva (multicellular) all belong to Chlorophyceae (green algae). They share the pigments chlorophyll a and b, cellulose cell walls, and starch as a storage product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not all multicellular (Chlamydomonas is unicellular). They are found in freshwater and marine habitats. They can reproduce both sexually and asexually. Their shared class is based on chlorophyll a and b and starch storage.

questions.question_text: Sphagnum (peat moss) is economically important because it:

options.text: Is a source of food for livestock
Can absorb and retain large amounts of water, making it useful as packing material and soil conditioner
Is used as a biofuel in power plants

questions.explanation_correct: Sphagnum (peat moss) has remarkable water-absorbing capacity, holding up to 20 times its dry weight in water. It is used as packing material for transporting live plants, as a soil conditioner, and accumulated deposits form peat (used as fuel).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sphagnum is not a food source for livestock, does not produce timber (it is a small moss), and while peat can be used as fuel, its primary economic importance is its water-absorbing capacity for horticultural and packing uses.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of structures in the life cycle of a moss?
questions.explanation_correct: In the moss life cycle: a haploid spore germinates to form a filamentous protonema, which develops buds that grow into the leafy gametophyte. After fertilisation on the gametophyte, the diploid sporophyte develops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct sequence is Spore → Protonema → Leafy gametophyte → Sporophyte. The protonema stage comes before the leafy gametophyte, not after. The sporophyte develops last, after fertilisation.

questions.question_text: Funaria is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Funaria is a common moss (Bryopsida). It has an upright leafy gametophyte and produces a sporophyte with a foot, seta, and capsule. It is widely used as a study organism in botany.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Marchantia is a liverwort, Dryopteris is a fern, and Pinus is a gymnosperm. Funaria is a classic example of a moss (Bryopsida).

questions.question_text: The female gametophyte of an angiosperm is the:
questions.explanation_correct: In angiosperms, the female gametophyte is the embryo sac, which develops within the ovule. It is highly reduced, typically consisting of only seven cells (including the egg cell, synergids, antipodals, and central cell).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovule is the megasporangium (sporophyte structure). The pollen grain is the male gametophyte. The megasporangium is a sporophyte structure. The embryo sac is the female gametophyte.

questions.question_text: Double fertilisation is a unique feature of:
questions.explanation_correct: Double fertilisation is unique to angiosperms. One sperm fuses with the egg cell to form the zygote (syngamy), and the second sperm fuses with the two polar nuclei to form the triploid primary endosperm nucleus (triple fusion).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Double fertilisation does not occur in bryophytes, pteridophytes, or gymnosperms. It is an exclusive feature of angiosperms, resulting in the formation of both the embryo and the nutritive endosperm tissue.

questions.question_text: In which plant group is the gametophyte reduced to just a few cells?
questions.explanation_correct: In angiosperms, the gametophyte is maximally reduced. The male gametophyte is the pollen grain (2-3 cells) and the female gametophyte is the embryo sac (7 cells). This represents the extreme of the evolutionary trend of gametophyte reduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In bryophytes, the gametophyte is the dominant phase. In pteridophytes, the gametophyte (prothallus) is small but free-living. In gymnosperms, the gametophyte is reduced but more developed than in angiosperms. Maximum reduction occurs in angiosperms.

questions.question_text: In the alternation of generations, spores are produced by:
questions.explanation_correct: Spores are produced by meiosis in the sporophyte (diploid phase). This is a key step in the life cycle because it reduces the chromosome number from 2n to n, producing haploid spores that grow into the gametophyte.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gametes (not spores) are produced by mitosis in the gametophyte. Spores are always produced by meiosis in the diploid sporophyte, not by mitosis. Meiosis does not occur in the gametophyte (which is already haploid).

questions.question_text: Sexual reproduction in Spirogyra occurs through:
questions.explanation_correct: Spirogyra reproduces sexually through conjugation, where the contents of one cell pass through a conjugation tube into another cell to form a zygospore. This is a type of non-flagellated gamete transfer unique to Spirogyra.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oogamy involves a large non-motile egg and small motile sperm. Isogamy with flagellated gametes occurs in Chlamydomonas. Zoospore formation is asexual. Conjugation is the characteristic sexual process in Spirogyra.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about pteridophytes is INCORRECT?

options.text: They possess true roots, stems, and leaves
The sporophyte is the dominant generation

questions.explanation_correct: Pteridophytes do NOT produce seeds. They reproduce via spores. Seed production first appears in gymnosperms. Pteridophytes have true vascular tissue and differentiated plant bodies but are non-seed-bearing vascular plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pteridophytes do possess true roots, stems, and leaves (A is correct), the sporophyte is dominant (B is correct), and they require water for the transport of flagellated sperms (D is correct). Only C is incorrect as they reproduce by spores, not seeds.

questions.question_text: The male cone and female cone in Pinus produce, respectively:
questions.explanation_correct: In Pinus, male cones (staminate cones) produce microspores that develop into pollen grains. Female cones (ovulate cones) bear megasporangia (ovules) that produce megaspores, which develop into the female gametophyte.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The male cone produces microspores (not megaspores). Ovules are borne on female cones (not produced by male cones). Gymnosperms do not produce fruits. Male cones produce microspores/pollen; female cones produce megaspores.

questions.question_text: The correct sequence of dominant generation in plant groups from most gametophyte-dominant to most sporophyte-dominant is:
questions.explanation_correct: The evolutionary trend shows progressive sporophyte dominance: Bryophytes (gametophyte dominant) → Pteridophytes (sporophyte dominant, free-living gametophyte) → Gymnosperms (sporophyte dominant, reduced gametophyte) → Angiosperms (sporophyte dominant, maximally reduced gametophyte).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sequence must start with bryophytes (most gametophyte-dominant) and end with angiosperms (most sporophyte-dominant). The correct evolutionary sequence is Bryophytes → Pteridophytes → Gymnosperms → Angiosperms.

questions.question_text: Sargassum is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Sargassum is a brown alga (Phaeophyceae) that forms large floating masses in the Sargasso Sea in the Atlantic Ocean. It contains fucoxanthin and chlorophyll a and c.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sargassum is not a green, red, or blue-green alga. It is a well-known brown alga (Phaeophyceae) that can form extensive floating beds in the ocean.

questions.question_text: The sporophyte of a bryophyte consists of:
questions.explanation_correct: The sporophyte of a bryophyte is a simple structure consisting of a foot (embedded in the gametophyte for nutrition), a seta (stalk), and a capsule (which produces spores by meiosis).
questions.explanation_incorrect: True roots, stems, and leaves are found in vascular plants, not bryophyte sporophytes. Rhizoids and leaf-like structures are part of the gametophyte. Prothallus is the fern gametophyte. The bryophyte sporophyte has foot, seta, and capsule.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is common to both gymnosperms and angiosperms?

options.text: Presence of companion cells in phloem

questions.explanation_correct: Both gymnosperms and angiosperms are seed-bearing plants (spermatophytes). This is their most significant shared feature. However, gymnosperms have naked seeds while angiosperms have seeds enclosed in fruits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Double fertilisation is unique to angiosperms. Fruit-enclosed seeds are an angiosperm feature. Companion cells in phloem are found in angiosperms but not gymnosperms (which have albuminous cells). Seed formation is the common feature.

questions.question_text: Heterospory is the production of two different types of spores. This phenomenon is a precursor to:
questions.explanation_correct: Heterospory (production of microspores and megaspores) is considered a precursor to the seed habit. The retention of the megaspore within the megasporangium and its development into a female gametophyte within the sporangium eventually led to the evolution of seeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heterospory is unrelated to vegetative reproduction, fragmentation, or binary fission. The production of two types of spores (micro and mega) is an evolutionary step towards the development of seeds.

questions.question_text: Algae reproduce by all of the following methods EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: Algae do NOT produce seeds. They reproduce vegetatively (fragmentation), asexually (zoospores, aplanospores), and sexually (isogamy, anisogamy, oogamy). Seed formation is a feature of gymnosperms and angiosperms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fragmentation (A), zoospore formation (B), and various forms of sexual reproduction including isogamy, anisogamy, and oogamy (D) all occur in algae. Only seed formation (C) does not occur in algae.

questions.question_text: The first land plants to develop a vascular system were:
questions.explanation_correct: Pteridophytes were the first land plants to evolve a true vascular system (xylem and phloem). This allowed them to grow taller and transport water and nutrients more efficiently than bryophytes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bryophytes lack true vascular tissue. While gymnosperms and angiosperms also have vascular tissue, pteridophytes were the first group to develop it in evolutionary history.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic of monocotyledons?

options.text: Two cotyledons, reticulate venation, tap root system
One cotyledon, parallel venation, fibrous root system
One cotyledon, reticulate venation, tap root system
Two cotyledons, parallel venation, fibrous root system

questions.explanation_correct: Monocotyledons are characterised by one cotyledon in the seed, parallel venation in leaves, fibrous root system, trimerous flowers, and scattered vascular bundles in the stem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two cotyledons, reticulate venation, and tap root system are features of dicotyledons. Monocotyledons have one cotyledon, parallel venation, and fibrous roots. The features listed in B are all correct monocot characters.

questions.question_text: The cell wall composition of green algae is similar to that of higher plants because both contain:
questions.explanation_correct: Green algae (Chlorophyceae) and higher plants both have cell walls composed primarily of cellulose. This similarity in cell wall composition, along with shared pigments (chlorophyll a and b), supports the evolutionary origin of land plants from green algae.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chitin is in fungi, silica in diatoms, and peptidoglycan in bacteria. Both green algae and higher plants share cellulose as their primary cell wall component, indicating their evolutionary relationship.

questions.question_text: The male sex organs in bryophytes are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Antheridia are the male sex organs in bryophytes (and in pteridophytes). They produce biflagellate male gametes called antherozoids. Archegonia are the female sex organs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Archegonia are female sex organs, sporangia produce spores, and strobili are cone-like structures in some pteridophytes and gymnosperms. Antheridia are the male reproductive organs in bryophytes.

questions.question_text: Sequoia (redwood) is one of the tallest trees on Earth. It belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Sequoia is a gymnosperm belonging to the family Cupressaceae (previously Taxodiaceae). It is a conifer that produces naked seeds in cones. Sequoia sempervirens (coast redwood) is the tallest known living tree species.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sequoia is not an angiosperm (it does not produce flowers or fruits), pteridophyte (it produces seeds), or bryophyte (it is a large tree). It is a gymnosperm (conifer).

questions.question_text: In the life cycle of an angiosperm, the haploid structures are:

options.text: Pollen grain (male gametophyte) and embryo sac (female gametophyte)
Root and shoot of the seedling

questions.explanation_correct: In angiosperms, the haploid (n) structures are the pollen grain (male gametophyte) and the embryo sac (female gametophyte). All other parts of the flowering plant are diploid (2n), including the ovary, anther wall, embryo, root, and shoot. The endosperm is triploid (3n).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ovary and anther are diploid sporophyte structures. The embryo is diploid and endosperm is triploid. Root and shoot are diploid. Only the gametophytic structures (pollen grain and embryo sac) are haploid.
